abstract.text: A view controller that manages an OpenGL ES rendering loop.

inlineContent.text: A
object works in conjunction with a
object to display frames of animation in the view, and also provides standard view controller functionality.
To use this class, allocate and initialize a new
subclass and set its
property to point to a
object. Then, configure the view controller’s

property to the desired frame rate your application requires. You can set a delegate or configure other properties on the view controller, such as whether the animation loop is automatically paused or resumed when the application moves into the background.
When you set the
property to point to a
object, if the view does not already have a delegate, then the view controller is automatically set as the view’s delegate.
When active, rendering loop automatically updates the view’s contents each time a new frame must be displayed. Each frame is rendered by the view controller using these steps:
The view controller calls its delegate’s
method. Your delegate should update frame data that does not involve rendering the results to the screen.
The view controller calls its view’s
method. Your view should redraw the frame.
Your application should subclass
and override the
and
methods. Your
method should set up your context and any drawable properties and can perform other resource allocation and initialization. Similarly, your class’s
method should delete the drawable object and free any unneeded resources.
As an alternative to implementing a
method in a delegate, your subclass can provide an update method instead. The method must have the following signature:

abstract.text: The view that the controller manages.
Called after the controller’s view is loaded into memory.
Called when the controller's view is released from memory.
Speed up OpenGL ES or OpenGL app development. Use math libraries, background texture loading, pre-created shader effects, and a standard view and view controller to implement your rendering loop.
A default implementation for views that draw their content using OpenGL ES.
Redraws the view’s contents immediately.
A view controller that manages an OpenGL ES rendering loop.
The view controller’s delegate.
The number of frame updates that have been sent by the view controller since it was created.
The actual rate that the view controller attempts to call the view to update its contents.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the rendering loop is paused.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view controller automatically pauses the rendering loop when the application resigns the active state.
The rate you want the view controller to call the view to update the contents of the view.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the view controller automatically resumes the rendering loop when the application becomes active.
The amount of time that has passed since first time the view controller resumed sending update events.
The amount of time that has passed since the last time the view controller called the view’s
method.
The amount of time that has passed since the last time the view controller resumed sending update events.
The amount of time that has passed since the last time the view controller called the delegate’s
method.
Rendering loop callback methods for use with a
object.
Called before each frame is displayed.
Drawing callback methods for use with a
object.
An object that manages a view hierarchy for your UIKit app.
A protocol that enables an object to be encoded and decoded for archiving and distribution.
The interface an app extension uses to respond to a request from a host app.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
An interface that provides a source for shareable content to fulfill user requests to share current content.
A protocol that a class must adopt to allow appearance customization using the [`UIAppearance`](doc://com.apple.uikit/documentation/UIKit/UIAppearance) API.
A set of methods for adapting the contents of your view controllers to size and trait changes.
A set of methods that define the focus behavior for a branch of the view hierarchy.
The interface that determines whether a responder object supports paste configuration.
A set of standard methods that apps can adopt to support editing.
Methods for adding objects to your state restoration archives.
A set of methods that makes the iOS interface environment available to your app.
The protocol you adopt to restore an object’s state from a user activity.
A type that calls your code in reaction to changes in the trait environment.
A type that can be hashed into a `Hasher` to produce an integer hash value.
A type that can be compared for value equality.
A singleton actor whose executor is equivalent to the main dispatch queue.
A type with a customized textual representation.
A type with a customized textual representation suitable for debugging purposes.
A type whose instances can be encoded, and appropriately passed, as elements of a C `va_list`.
A thread-safe type whose values can be shared across arbitrary concurrent contexts without introducing a risk of data races.
